author: Trey Williams
title: Netflix’s aggressive global expansion may not pay off until 2018
text:
Netflix Inc.’s foray into foreign markets won’t pay off until 2018, according to Standard & Poor’s.
The streaming video company’s effort to build business abroad has been successful so far, S&P analyst Andy Liu wrote in a research note published earlier Thursday, but it’s likely to get tougher.
In his note, Liu wrote that as Netflix NFLX, +6.84% continues its 200-country expansion plan, set to be complete by the end of 2016, he expects the streaming giant to incur discretionary cash flow deficits of at least $1 billion both this year and next.
Also read: Netflix CEO wants to take over the world
“Netflix will likely need to raise new financing in 2016 or very early in 2017 to fund operations and expansions,” Liu wrote. “If its newly launched markets move steadily toward profitability and original content investments remain stable as a percentage of overall content budget, Netflix’s discretionary cash flow deficit could decline meaningfully in 2017.
“However, we don’t expect positive discretionary cash flow until 2018, at the earliest,” he wrote.
S&P holds a B+ rating on Netflix, marking its debt as it a risky investment. As Netflix spends money to make the jump into foreign markets, Liu wrote, the company is likely to face stiff competition from established players. With plans to launch in Japan, Spain, Italy and Portugal later this year, Liu wrote, Netflix will likely need to invest in new, market-specific content.
Don’t miss: Netflix has star-studded original content up its sleeve
“Most content licensing agreements for Netflix and its peers are for specific markets and involve separate negotiations, which elevate costs,” Liu wrote. “With global licensing agreements, Netflix could streamline the process somewhat and possibly lower its licensing costs. Netflix will need to be very selective in pursuing these global agreements, however, because if a specific show doesn’t translate well to international markets, it could quickly strain the company’s content budget.”
Subscriber growth for Netflix in 2015 has been ahead of S&P’s expectations. If that continues, Liu wrote, it could warrant revising the company’s outlook to stable from negative.
“On the other hand, if subscriber growth is significantly below our expectations, such that we believe it could limit Netflix’s access to capital markets, we could downgrade the company further,” Liu wrote.
